snippet: The surfaces of grapes may harbor different species of yeast microbes, which could be related to variances in sun exposure and temperature.
abstract: Dr Evodia Setati research in journal PLoS One finds that grapes from different parts of the same vineyard can be quite different because their surfaces harbor different types of yeast microbes; such variations, which can affect wine flavor, are most present in biodynamic farms, which use a specialized type of organic farming that includes fermented herbal and mineral preparations as compost additives.
lead_paragraph: The surfaces of grapes may harbor different species of yeast microbes, which could be related to variances in sun exposure and temperature.

headline.seo: Same Grapes Can Vary by Location in Vineyard
headline.main: Grapes Can Be Different by Location in Vineyard
headline.print_headline: Grapes Can Be Different By Location in Vineyard
